title: CTRL0000916057 - Transcribed Interview of Douglas C. Sellers, Jr., (June 3, 2022)

data.text: SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE THE
JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES,
WASHINGTON, D.C.
INTERVIEW OF:
DOUGLAS SELLERS
Friday, June 3, 2022
Washington, D.C.
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:00 p.m.
Appearances:
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
TAFF ASSOCIATE
SENIOR INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
ROFESSIONAL STAFF MEMBER
SENIOR INVESTIGATIVE COUNSEL
For DOUGLAS SELLERS:
STEFAN PASSANTINO
Good morning.
This is a transcribed interview conducted by the
House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the U.S. Capitol
pursuant to House Resolution 503.
My name i s _ , I'm a senior investigative counsel; and with me i s -
who is also a senior investigative counsel.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state and spell your last name -- state
your full name and spell your last name.
Mr. Sellers.
Sure.
Douglas Sellers, S-e-1-1-e-r-s.
Mr. Sellers, thank you for joining us and doing so voluntarily.
I'm
going to go over a few ground rules before we get started, but first let me say that, while
and I are here in the room today, and we're doing this by Webex, we may be
joined at any point by members of the select committee, and if they do join they can ask
questions, but as it stands now it's just the two of us and we'll be the ones asking
questions, okay?
Mr. Sellers.
Okay.
record.
Mr. Passantino.
Now, there is an official reporter who is transcribing the interview today, Mr.
Stefan Passantino, P-a-s-s-a-n-t-i-n-o.
Sellers, and, as you heard at the start, it is also being recorded on video.
In order to keep the record as clean as possible, we just ask that you wait for us to
complete our questions before you begin your answer, and we'll wait for you complete
your answer before we ask our next question.
If anything we ask is unclear, please just say so.
We'll do our best to rephrase
the question or make it clear for you.
record nonverbal responses like a shake or nod of the head, so excuse me in advance if at
any point we have to ask you to say yes or no or to verbalize your response.
And just to note that the official reporter can't
So as we go through the questions today, all you're being asked is to provide the
most complete answer you can, based on your best recollection of the events.
don't remember something or you don't know the answer, just say so.
If at any point you need a break to talk to Mr. Passantino, or you just need a break
for comfort, we're happy to accommodate.
off and go on mute and just take a few minutes, whatever you need.
If you
Just let us know.
We can turn our cameras
And before we get started I mentioned, but I'll say now on the record, we're going
to show you some exhibits today, some documents and a photograph.
time as you need, and if you need to take a break with your attorney to look at those to
familiarize yourself with them before you answer any questions.
Take as much
What we'll do is we'll flash them up on the screen, and if you need us to
direct -- you know, to zoom in so you can see them more clearly, just let us know.
Otherwise, I'll just remind you, as we do all witnesses, that it is unlawful to
deliberately provide false information to Congress and that to do so could result in
criminal penalties.
Do you understand all that?
Mr. Sellers.
Yes.
Do you have any questions before we get started?
Mr. Sellers.
I don't believe so, no.
Thank you.
And, as I said earlier and will just make clear for the record, you're
appearing voluntarily.
We reached out to you and you retained Mr. Passantino and
agreed to meet with us without the need for a subpoena.
Is that right?
Mr. Sellers.
Yes.
Thank you.
Now, as part of our reach-out to Mr. Passantino and
our conversations about your appearance, we also made several requests for documents,
to the extent you had them.
made through Mr. Passantino?
Mr. Sellers.
Were you generally familiar with the requests that we
Yes.
And as I understand from Mr. Passantino, you don't have anything
responsive that is -- that falls within the categories and the timeframe that we asked for.
Is that right?
Mr. Sellers.
That is correct, yes.
But just so we're clear, did you make an effort to look through
whatever electronic devices or hard copy files you have to see if you had anything
responsive?
Mr. Sellers.
I did, yes.
I looked at my phone and don't really have any
hard-copy documents, but I did ensure that I didn't have any of the documents in the
request.
Thank you for doing that.
EXAMINATION
BY
All right.
Q
with all witnesses.
So then we'll start with a few background questions, as we do
How old are you, Mr. Sellers?
A
Thirty-one.
Q
And what's the highest level of education you have?
A
Bachelor's degree.
Q
What year did you graduate?
A
Q
And from what school?
A
Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas.
Q
What is your current occupation?
A
I'm -- I have my own company.
Q
And prior to that, we understand you worked in the White House for
President Trump's administration.
I'm a consultant.
Is that right?
A
That's correct.
Q
And what year did you join the White House?
A
Well, so I -- I worked in the EOP and 0MB in 2017 for about a year -- or
almost a year.
now called the DFC, for a year and a half, and then left government for about a year, and
then started working in the White House in -- at the very end of May 2020 through
January 2020 -- 2021, excuse me.
I worked at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, OPIC, which is
Q
Was your last day in your role at the White House roughly January 20th of
A
I -- it was actually January 7th.
Q
All right.
I -- yeah.
We'll come back to that.
It was January 7th.
But when you joined in May of 2020,
what role did you join -- did you come on as with the White House?
A
I believe my title was assistant staff secretary, but I joined as a member of
the staff secretary's office.
Q
Did your role remain the same throughout your tenure, from May of 2020
through January of 2021?
A
Yes.
I mean, Derek Lyons, who was staff secretary, left in December, but
that didn't really change the nature of my role upon him leaving and I was only there for a
week or two after he left.
Q
Staff Secretary?
A
But yes, it was pretty much the same role throughout.
As a general matter, what were your responsibilities within the Office of
I was just a member of the team, and we kind of had a few of us that had
played similar roles, in terms of staffing out documents, getting comments on executive
orders, Presidential memos, those sorts of things, talking points, speeches, and kind of
worked it through our process in order to get it prepared for final signature or for, you
know, delivery, or what have you.
So I just kind of was -- we all -- most of the folks on our team had similar roles in
that.
specialty or anything like that.
And I just was part of that, that team.
Q
So I didn't necessarily have like a set
We all were kind of team players and did similar work.
When it comes to speeches in particular, again, just in a summary fashion,
what was the role of the staff secretary's office?
A
So basically, we would get a speech from the speechwriting team, and then
circulate that speech to the relevant people in the EOP or the administration, depending
on the nature of it, and then collect comments for the speechwriting team.
would, you know, adjudicate those comments or that feedback.
Then they
And then we would -- we would sometimes do that, you know, multiple rounds,
depending on the nature of the speech or how long or et cetera, and then get it ready for
final presentation, and make a binder for the President and, you know, then put in the
speech text into the teleprompter if that were -- if it were a teleprompter speech, that
sort of thing.
So just kind of coordinating input and feedback on speeches.
In terms of background, I don't have any more questions.
know if Mr. -
I don't
does.
I don't, no, thank you.
Q
Okay.
So I think we can just kind of cut to the chase, Mr. Sellers, with
showing you exhibit 2.
It's a photograph -- I'll tell you before it flashes on the screen or
as it's coming up -- that was taken on the evening of January 5th of 2021 in the Oval
Office.
And as we understand it, it was roughly around 5 p.m. in the evening.
So do you see that photograph on your screen?
A
Yes.
Q
And as we understand it, if we look at the photo, President Trump is on the
Yes, I do.
right, and then as you follow the photo, you work from right to left.
Do you recognize the young woman who's standing next to him at the Resolute
Are you able to see it?
Desk?
A
Yes.
Q
And then to her left?
A
To her left is me -- or, excuse me, to her right.
Q
As we look at the photo, it reverses the perspective.
A
Yeah, I have to flip over.
Q
Let me just start by asking this:
That's my colleague, Madison Porter.
I'm looking --
I'm to Madison's right.
Do you remember being in the Oval Office
that night of January 5th of 2021?
A
Yes.
Q
Why were you there?
A
I was there with Madison to help her.
Sorry.
We were both there together to get
the President to sign, I believe, a lot of legislation that was soon to expire if he weren't to
sign it.
of -- or documents signed that evening.
And so we were getting that, and maybe a few other orders or, you know, pieces
I know that it was a lot of legislation.
I think -- I think you can see some of it on
the corner of the desk there.
went to help her carry them and then get them signed.
Understood.
Q
But I know that there were kind of stacks of them, and I
Now, when you and Ms. Porter went in to have those signed,
were all of the other people that we see in that meeting, putting President Trump aside,
were all of the other people there when you first came in the Oval Office, that you
remember?
A
being a crowd.
two in the room in addition to the President, but I remember -- I definitely remember it
not being everyone in that picture when we initially went in.
Q
When we first went in, I think it was just the two of us.
I don't remember it
I don't remember if we were the only three in -- or if we were the only
In terms of everyone else in the picture besides the three people we've now
discussed, could you just work your way around the picture in the same direction.
don't have to do the left-right, but just who you recognize being in there, starting next to
you on the other side, not Ms. Porter.
A
So who's that, if you can tell us?
Kayleigh McEnany is in the red sweater.
Martin in the -- in the -- next to her in the dark outfit.
doorway.
whose name that is, is Davis Ingle.
We
And then I think that's Margo
I do not remember who is in the
And then, I believe, that the man next to -- who I do not -- I'm not recalling
And then I believe next to him is Gaby Hurt.
I cannot remember her last name, but I believe the woman next to her is Lindy, I
think, is her first name.
The gentleman next -- under the clock is Chad -- Chad Gilmartin,
I believe.
or the other two behind the lamp.
And then I'm not -- I'm not sure I remember the woman's name next to him,
And then I see Judd Deere standing in the gray suit,
and it looks like the back of Dan Scavino's head in this picture as well.
Q
Now, Mr. Scavino aside, all of the people that you just discussed from
Kayleigh McEnany through Judd Deere, were they all, to the best of your knowledge, part
of, I guess, which office?
A
The press team or the communications team.
I'm not sure.
I guess
communications team is the right way to put it.
Q
So you and Ms. Porter were the only people in the room at that time who
were from the staff secretary's office?
A
That is correct.
Q
Now, when you and Ms. Porter came into the Oval Office, I know you said
earlier you recall the President being there, but did you remember Mr. Scavino being
there when you first joined, or did he come later?
A
I do not recall that.
Q
You talked about the door in the picture, right in the center where the young
woman is standing who you don't know the name of, and it appears that the door is open
to the outside.
A
Yes.
Q
All right.
in the Oval Office?
A
I do.
Q
So I think it would be helpful -- and you take your time if you need a minute
Is that right?
Do you remember the door being open that night when you were
I do.
to review and go over with Mr. Passantino.
I'm going to show you exhibit 3, and what exhibit 3 is, is an excerpt from the book,
"Peril," by the authors and reporters Bob Woodward and Robert Costa.
first page 1 that shows you the title page?
Do you see that
A
Yes, I do.
Q
All right.
So we'll go to page 2 of the exhibit, and page 2 are the pages in
the book 230 and 231, and then just to show you page 3 of the exhibit is pages 232 and
Now, if you go back to page 2, what we've done is we've just highlighted a
description in Peril of the meeting that took place within the Oval Office the night of
January 5th that that photo was of.
And so, what I'd like you to do is just read the highlighted portion to yourself.
And if you want to take a break and talk to Mr. Passantino about it, you let us know.
if you -- we can zoom in as close as you need, and just when you're done let us know.
Doug, are you able to see that?
Mr. Sellers.
Yes, I'm able to see it.
I'm happy to read it right now.
But
Okay, I've
read the 230 and 231 highlighted sections.
Q
So let's move to page 3 of the exhibit.
Let us know when you're done reading that.
A
Okay.
Q
Are you good?
A
Yes, I read all the highlighted section.
Q
Okay.
I don't -- I don't necessarily remember the -- the conversation that was
A
described there.
So is the description within Peril, is that consistent with what you
remember about the meeting that night?
There's just one last paragraph.
I don't really recall the quotes or what was said in the room.
I do remember the room, the door was open, and I -- I personally don't remember
shivering or being cold, but I don't know that I would necessarily remember that.
Q
What -- and I guess you were in -- as we see in the photo, you were in a full
suit, although some of your colleagues maybe had on dresses or sleeveless dresses, so
understood.
But in terms of the meeting then, and understanding that you might not recall the
particular quotes, do you remember discussion of the people who had come to D.C. for
the President's rally and hearing the music?
A
I remember hearing pretty faint sounds of music in the background.
I don't
know that I remember hearing like people or crowds.
And I know that there -- I don't
really remember the contents of the conversation.
I know that there might have been
some comment made about the people outside, but I don't really recall any sort of
discussion, or any sort of -- the details of any conversation about the events or the -- what
was going on outside.
Q
But as a general matter, do you recall that the President was discussing the
fact that there were people there in town, beside the specifics?
A
Yes.
As a general matter, I think -- I mean, I recall him making mention of
people being in town, but I don't really necessarily remember the nature of those
comments or anything like that.
Q
Were you there when the door to the outside was actually opened, or was it
opened by the time you got in that evening?
Do you remember?
A
I do not remember that.
Q
Do you recall -- you see Mr. Scavino sitting there in the photo and his phone
is out.
Do you see that?
Did you see that in exhibit 2?
A
I did, yes.
Q
Do you remember there being discussion of any tweets or the President
sending out any tweets at that time?
A
I don't remember that or those sorts of discussions.
Q
Okay.
Do you recall any discussion by the President, put aside the people
who were in town, but about what was going to happen the next day at the joint session
of Congress for the certification of the Presidential election?
A
I do not recall, no.
Q
Did he -- did the President discuss that, though, and you just don't
remember the specifics?
A
day.
He may have.
He may have.
I just -- I don't really -- I don't recall any talk about the next
I just don't -- I don't recall.
Q
If we look at exhibit 4 -- we'll bring that up for you, Mr. Sellers.
A
Okay.
Q
And what this is is just an archive of President Trump's tweets.
And so, the
first page, it starts with tweets that he sent on January 6th, but I want to direct you to
page 4.
And if you look at page 4, what we've done is highlighted three that were sent out,
the first at 5:05 p.m. on the night of January 5th, the second at 5:12 p.m. on January 5th,
and the third at 5:25 p.m. on January 5.
Do you see those there?
A
Yes, I do see them.
Q
If you could just let us know when you're done reading them to yourself.
A
Okay.
Q
So I just want to talk about these a little bit.
Okay, I've read all three.
But you notice that the timing
is in line with when we understand this meeting in the Oval Office was taking place, which
is in the 5 o'clock hour.
Do you recall that being about the time you were in there, in the office?
A
I don't recall the time of when I would have been in there.
Q
Was it within business hours, though?
A
I don't know what business hours technically are, but, I mean, I remember it
being dark and, I mean, I remember it being like towards the end of a workday.
mean, at the end of a workday sort of thing.
Q
So yes, I
And you notice there that in the first tweet that we've highlighted, the 5:50
p.m., the President says, "We hear you (and love you) from the Oval Office," and he's
talking about at the start that Washington is being inundated with people who don't want
to see an election victory stolen.
Do you see that?
A
Yes.
Q
Does that refresh your recollection about whether you heard or could hear
people within the Oval Office at that time outside, and that the President was
commenting on the fact that people were there in town?
A
I don't -- I don't recall necessarily hearing people outside.
Again, I recall
like music and, I mean, maybe faint -- I think you could kind of always hear, like, noises of
the city from outside, but I don't necessarily recall like hearing a loud crowd or anything
of that -- of that nature.
Q
And in his next tweet just a few minutes later at 5:12, he's talking about
weak and ineffective RINO section of the Republican Party, and he tweets out certain
Senators, Senator McConnell, Senator Cornyn, and Senator Thune.
Do you see that?
A
Yes, I see that.
Q
So, as we read in the Peril book, where it says there was discussion about
RINOs, and what to do about the RINOs, this tweet is in line with that.
Does that refresh your memory about whether the President was discussing that
in the room with you all?
A
I don't recall that, that specifically.
Q
At minute 5:25 p.m., you see that he sends a tweet about antifa being a
terrorist organization, stay out of Washington, law enforcement is watching you.
And if you recall, in the Peril section you read, there is discussion about the
President saying there's a lot of anger out there, and a staffer commenting that they hope
it was going to be safe the next day, and so, consistent with the tweet that's sent at 5:25
talking about law enforcement watching.
So, again, does that refresh your recollection about whether there was discussion
in that room by the President about whether it would be safe in the city on January 6th?
A
I do not recall that, that conversation, no.
Q
What, if anything, more do you recall about your time in the Oval Office that
night and what was discussed?
A
I really don't have a great recollection of what was discussed.
remember getting out of the way when the group took a picture.
picture, I remember, and that's when I think that we left.
But I don't really recall the conversations.
I do
There was a big group
I just -- I really remember just being in
there to get documents signed and then -- and then kind of being -- getting out when the
group of the press team took a picture, I believe.
Q
So regarding the President's, what, if anything, he was saying that night, you
know, you see the last tweet there is at 5:25 p.m., right?
A
Yes, I see that.
Q
That we highlighted.
So why don't we look at exhibit 5.
Okay.
I'm just going to orient you that this is an
email chain that starts on January 5th, and actually ends on January 5th, but the last -- the
top email in the chain that you're looking on page 1, if we go -- stay up there at the top,
please, it's from Ross Worthington sent to a collection of people.
And it's listed as being at 12:46 a.m. on January 6th.
For your orientation, this is
actually in Greenwich Mean Time, so that's actually 7:46 p.m. on the 5th.
A
Okay.
Q
And included on there, you see at the top the first recipient is Austin Ferrer,
but then the next one is Madison Porter.
But what I want to do, then, is go to the first
email in the chain to show you how it started.
Okay.
So it's on page 2.
Go back up to page 2.
So there you see that January 5th at 5:11 p.m. Austin Ferrer writes to Vince Haley
and Ross Worthington, copying the staff secretary email address and also Molly Michael,
and the subject line is the 11 a.m. speech.
"Is a draft available for POTUS' speech tomorrow a.m.?
And then Mr. Ferrer is asking Vincent Ross:
Thank you.
Austin."
So can you see that all?
A
Yes, I can see those emails.
Q
Who are Mr. Haley and Mr. Worthington?
A
Mr. Haley and Mr. Worthington were two of the -- two members of the
speechwriting team.
Q
Who was Mr. Ferrer?
A
Mr. Ferrer was -- we called it the body man or the President's, you know,
personal aide.
Q
I'm not sure what his exact title was, but --
And the staff secretary email address that's copied on this asking about the
speech, was that an email address that would come to you and your colleagues in the
staff secretary office?
A
Yes, that is correct.
Q
If you notice the timing, 5:11 p.m., that's in between when the first tweet we
showed you from the President at 5:05 p.m. talking about the -- Washington being
inundated with people, and the 5:12 p.m. tweet talking about RINOs and what they'll do
the next day at the joint session.
So I want to show you the next email in the chain.
So we have to go to the
bottom of page 1, and it will come back to the top of page 2.
So there you can see that Madison Porter at 5:28 p.m. writes to Mr. Ferrer,
Mr. Haley, and Mr. Worthington, copies the Staff Secretary email address and Molly
Michael.
Vince -- we got some feedback from POTUS re: the remarks.
again, this is at 5:28 p.m., 3 minutes after the President had sent the last tweet talking
about antifa and law enforcement.
If we go down then to page 2 to read the text, and says:
"Ross and
Will give you a call."
So do you recall the President giving you and Ms. Porter feedback to provide to
Ross and Vince for his speech the next day?
A
I do not.
And I would just say, I guess, like, I don't -- I know that I didn't
work on this speech per se, because my last day was supposed to be the 6th.
kind of handed off a lot of my duties and responsibilities.
And so, I
And so, I do not remember any sort of direction, but I also might not have gotten
any direction, because Madison was staying on for the next couple weeks and may
have -- may have gotten some sort of direction.
feedback or direction there.
Q
But I do not recall receiving any sort of
This is -- you see there that Mr. Ferrer is asking is a draft available for the
speech, and here Ms. Porter is saying before a draft is circulated:
feedback from POTUS re: the remarks.
And,
"We got some
Will give you a call."
If you go up to the next email in the chain on page 1, Vince replies to Austin at
latest."
"Austin -- we are finalizing the draft.
We anticipate delivery by 8 p.m.
So what this reflects is that no draft had made its way to the President yet.
terms of your experience with the staff secretary's office, was it in the ordinary course for
the President to provide feedback about a speech to the staff secretary without having
seen a draft first?
A
So I guess I would just say it really varied on the speech.
So, in
And there were
times I recall when the President would work -- or would correspond with the
speechwriting team directly in the course of drafting a speech and that, you know, we
wouldn't necessarily be in the middle of that exchange if the President, you know, gave
specific instructions to the speechwriting team.
So, I think that that had happened in the past, just depending on the speech, in
terms of the President interacting with the speechwriting team in the course of them
drafting it.
Q
But here he is telling -- Ms. Porter is saying that the President gave -- well,
she says "we" feedback, and she copies the staff secretary and then is reaching out to
speechwriters.
So in terms of giving the staff secretary's office feedback before seeing a draft and
not reaching out to the speechwriters directly, was that in the ordinary course, in your
experience?
A
I -- I don't really know if that was in the ordinary course or not.
I guess -- I
think there could have been times in the past when the President, who I think knew that
the staff secretary team worked with the speechwriting team on speeches, would
mention to really anyone on either of the teams that he wanted something to be in the
remarks.
So I don't know that that was necessarily out of the ordinary, just in terms of
letting someone on either team know that he wanted something to be reflected in the
remarks.
Q
Speaking of wanting something reflected in the remarks, we're going to
show you two exhibits in a row to show you how that draft ends up coming.
look up at the top of this exhibit, to orient you, on the exhibit 4 -- excuse me, exhibit 5
still -- exhibit 5, my apologies -- that's Mr. Worthington, that top one at 7:45 p.m. on the
5th, saying:
"Draft attached -- please confirm receipt and delivery.
And the draft he sent is on this email.
But if you
Thank you."
Now, we can show you, starting on page
3, and I just want you to focus on that first paragraph and just read it to yourself and let
us know when you're done.
A
Okay.
Q
And do you recognize within that first paragraph the same kind of language
Okay, I've read the first paragraph.
that was in the President's tweets at the times I showed you on the night of the 5th?
For instance, our country has had enough and will not take it anymore, don't want to see
our election victory stolen by emboldened radical left Democrats.
If it helps you to look at the tweets, I'm happy to bring them back up.
want to compare that?
A
question, I guess?
Q
I mean, I recall I think the tweets.
And sorry, could you just restate your
Well, do you see that language there, starting with the last two sentences in
that opening paragraph?
A
Okay.
Q
Right?
Do you
page 4.
And then we'll just compare them just so you can see it on exhibit 4,
And the 5:05 tweet, if you just read that to yourself again.
A
[Witness reviewed the document.]
Q
Do you recognize the similar verbiage and words between that tweet and
what's in the opening paragraph of the speech?
A
Yes.
Q
Okay.
So then, if we look at exhibit 6, this is an earlier version of the
speech that Mr. Worthington sent to Stephen Miller, copying Vince Haley and Robert
Gabriel, on January 5th at 3:30 p.m., so 4 hours before that draft he circulated later.
I'll just stop here and ask, was it your understanding of the speechwriting process
that the team, you know, Mr. Worthington and Mr. Haley, would work with Mr. Miller to
get a draft in good shape before sending it in to the staff secretary review process?
A
Yes.
My understanding was that the team worked together -- or, I mean,
the speechwriting team worked together before sending a draft, depending on the nature
of the speech.
Q
But yes, that's my understanding.
So if we look at the first paragraph of this speech on page 2 of the same
exhibit, just read the first -- you can read the first two paragraphs to yourself and just let
